results.title: Facing Up to Aids: sex in the '90s
results.brief_description: This documentary gives an insight into sex in the 90’s as a diverse range of people relate their attitudes and experiences and indicate how issues such as AIDS and safe sex have had an impact on their lives.

results.title: Facing up
results.creator_credit: Leigh Tilson, Curriculum Corporation and Moving Images
results.brief_description: Facing up explores the ways societal expectations and pressures related to gender can influence the lives and health of young people. It is presented in three parts and includes some animated scenes. Part 1 - Shaping up: focuses on body image; the perfect body, both male and female; keeping fit; dieting; advertising and the exploitation of the female body; personal expectations. Part 2 - Hanging out: deals with personal problems/relationships; stereotype and gender roles; attitudes towards sex and contraception. Part 3 - Moving on: contemplates the future and becoming adults; responsibility, career, marriage, children, independence, choice and what it means to be an adult. Cast includes Adele Daniele, Amanda Jane, Richard Norton, Damien Walshe-Howling, Joanna Cooper, Stuart Atkin and students from Fitzroy Secondary College, Darebin Parklands Secondary College, Ashwood College and Ardoch Windsor College. This kit has been produced as a teaching aid for secondary level and includes a Teacher’s Guide and a Student Magazine.

results.title: Facing the music
results.creator_credit: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Stefan Moore and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A compelling portrait of the struggle endured by Sydney University’s Music Department as it withstands ongoing funding cuts. At the centre of this portrait is Head of the Department, Professor Anne Boyd, a renowned composer in her own right, whose passion for music is matched by her staunch commitment to quality higher education. Boyd’s idealism is what makes her an inspiring, impassioned teacher in the classroom and a fierce defender of education at union meetings and strikes. Filmed over one academic year, “Facing the music” reveals in excruciating detail the sacrifices, emotional strain and tattered morale a university department must endure when faced with sustained cuts. “Facing the music” is made by Australia’s award-winning documentary duo, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson, who, through capturing this real-life story, force us to consider the wider issue and debate of higher education within a context of economic rationalism. Should students fight for their right to quality education? Should Professors become entrepreneurs to ensure the survival of their academic departments? Should the arts suffer solely because it isn’t designed to sustain commerce and the marketplace? This is an extremely well-crafted, socially pertinent documentary that forces us to consider the role and worth of knowledge, research and the role of the artist in an increasingly hostile world of economic rationalism.

results.title: Facing the demons
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Dee Cameron and ARC
results.brief_description: This confronting video is an interesting study of violent crime explored from both the perspective of the victim’s family and the men who carried out the senseless crime. On the victims side are the mother and father, as well as friends and co-workers. On the other are two of the four men convicted of the murder. In the middle, mediating, is Senior Sergeant Terry O’Connell of the NSW Police Service. The meeting offers an opportunity for all those traumatized by the event to hear the other side of the story. It allows all parties the chance to air their feelings and opinions and to vent pent up emotions. The outcome for the viewer though is the reiteration that crime is truly senseless.

results.title: Facing new weapons
results.creator_credit: Philip Dorte, John Elliot, Air Ministry and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “War in the Air”.
This series of films, telling of the story of air power and its impact on the world was specially compiled by the BBC in 1954-55, 90% from actual combat material. The remainder consists of extracts from war documentary films and sequences constructed and specially shot by the BBC Production Unit with the co-operation and advice of the services. This episode focuses on air operations in Western Europe summer and autumn 1944.

results.title: Facing it: my friend's an alcoholic
results.creator_credit: William Haugse, George McQuilkin and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Terry, 17, has a drinking and drug problem and his friend, A.J., is being drawn into it. A.J. at first covers for Terry, then tries to intervene. Finally he realises, with the assistance of Terry’s girlfriend, that they need outside help.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Haugse, George McQuilkin and Churchill Films

results.title: Facing facts
results.creator_credit: Barrie Smith, Peter Dimond and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: The death of a close friend affects Glen Turner so much that he reflects on how his own death would affect his family’s financial security. In a discussion with an Officer of a Trustee company he learns of the steps he can take to alleviate any hardship in the event of unexpected tragedy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barrie Smith, Peter Dimond and Supreme Sound Studios

results.title: Faces of the enemy
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Friedman, Bill Jersey, Catticus and Quest
results.brief_description: Why do we see those with whom we are in conflict as monstrous and inhuman enemies? Recent events such as the fundamentalist Muslim death threats to Salman Rushdie or the upsurge of racist violence in Australia, raise questions about what drives nations and individuals to make monsters out of those they perceive as enemies. Faces of the Enemy is a fascinating yet disturbing film which presents a vivid picture of the ways in which societies create an image of the enemy, then become obsessed with this image to the point of being prepared to kill without guilt. In a chilling series of images we see the enemy depicted as demons, barbarians, madmen or vile animals to be exterminated without regret. Presented by Sam Keen
